metadata.case_name: Appellant (Manufacturer of Coconut Oil) v. Sales Tax Officer, 2nd Circle, Quilon

facts.text: Appellant is a registered manufacturer of coconut oil and cake, obtained certificate of registration in Form VI as per sub-r. (i) of r. 20 of the Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Rules, 1950.
Appellant's business consisted in purchase of copra, manufacture of coconut oil and cake, sale of same to parties inside the State of Travancore-Cochin and sale of oil to parties outside the State.
In the year 1951-52 (1st April 1951 to 31st March 1952), appellant purchased copra of value Rs. 7,16,048-1-4.

After manufacturing oil therefrom, appellant sold oil partly inside State (value Rs. 3,08,902-6-10) and partly outside State (Rs. 3,67,816-10-1), total oil sold Rs. 6,76,719-0-11; cake entirely within State (Rs. 67,155-15-5).

Appellant claimed deduction of whole purchase price of copra Rs. 7,16,048-1-4 under r. 7(i)(k) read with r. 20, arriving at net turnover Rs. 7,43,875-0-4; further deduct inter-State sales Rs. 3,67,816-10-1, net assessable turnover Rs. 3,76,058-6-3.

Sales Tax Officer fixed net assessable turnover at Rs. 7,54,144-8-4: took copra purchase Rs. 7,16,048-1-4, added oil sold inside Rs. 3,08,902-6-10 and cake Rs. 67,155-15-5 (excluding inter-State oil Rs. 3,67,816-10-1); deducted copra value corresponding to inside oil Rs. 3,35,216-0-0; added gum price Rs. 3,385-0-3; deducted sales tax collected Rs. 6,130-15-6.
Appellant appealed to Assistant Sales Tax Commissioner (S.T.A. No. 1480 of 1953-54), dismissed by order dated May 10, 1954.
Appellant filed Original Petition No. 53 of 1954 in High Court of Travancore-Cochin under Art. 226 for quashing STO order and directions; dismissed by order dated November 24, 1954.
Appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 132 with certificate of fitness.

legal_issues.text: Whether, for calculating net assessable turnover of registered manufacturer under Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act and Rules, inter-State sales of oil can be included in gross turnover to claim deduction of entire copra purchase price under r.7(1)(k) read with r.20, or must inter-State sales and corresponding copra value be entirely excluded due to s.26 incorporating Art.286 Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Entitled to deduct total copra purchase value Rs.7,16,048-1-4 against total oil sales Rs.6,76,719-0-11 (including inter-State), then further deduct inter-State oil sales Rs.3,67,816-10-1 under s.26.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Literal reading of ss.2(j),2(k),3, r.4, r.7(1)(k), r.20; s.26 only prohibits tax on inter-State sales but allows inclusion for deduction.

petitioner_arguments.text: In fiscal statutes, follow strict letter of law, not spirit; cannot tax by analogy.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Duke of Westminster; Partington v. Attorney General; Bank of Chettinad v. Income Tax Commissioner.

respondent_arguments.text: Inter-State sales of oil excluded entirely from turnover under s.26 non-obstante; no deduction of corresponding copra value; tax copra at purchase point for intra-State sales, avoid double tax only where applicable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.26 (incorporating Art.286); object of r.20 to avoid double taxation only for intra-State.

court_reasoning.text: Definitions in ss.2(j),2(k) and rr.4,7,20 include all sales without distinction inside/outside State prima facie; allows deduction of full copra value against total oil sales if included in turnover.

s.26 non-obstante clause sets aside inconsistent prior provisions; takes inter-State sales out of Act's purview entirelyâ€”no inclusion in gross/net turnover, no applicability of r.20 deduction for corresponding copra.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Obliterates charging provisions and r.20 for such sales.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction between no-liability to tax (excludes from turnover) vs exemptions (deduct from gross); s.26 enacts no-liability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No declaration of liability, no assessment includes them.

court_reasoning.text: Strict literal construction in fiscal statutes; but s.26 effect is to exclude inter-State transactions completely.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agree with High Court on purpose: tax copra purchase, concession avoids double tax only intra-State.

holdings.text: s.26 non-obstante provision excludes inter-State sales from turnover calculations; no inclusion of such sales value, no deduction under r.7(1)(k)/r.20 of corresponding copra purchase value.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Duke of Westminster
precedents_cited.relevance: Strict letter of fiscal law over spirit/substance.
If within letter, tax; else free despite spirit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bank of Chettinad v. Income Tax Commissioner
precedents_cited.relevance: Protest against substance over legal position in revenue cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: F.L. Smidth Co. v. F. Greenwood
Aswani Kumar Ghosh v. Arabinda Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Non-obstante clause sets aside inconsistent prior laws.

precedents_cited.case_name: Messrs. Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Three stages of tax (liability, assessment, recovery); no liability, no assessment.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Act, 1125 (Act XI of 1125 M.E.)
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of sale/turnover; charging section; rules power; s.26 non-obstante excludes inter-State sales from tax/turnover.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin General Sales Tax Rules, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Gross turnover (sales/purchases for certain goods); net turnover deductions; r.20 deduction for copra converted to oil/cake if oil sales included in turnover.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Appeal certificate; writ petition; restrictions on State sales tax for inter-State etc.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld; Sales Tax Officer's calculation of net assessable turnover at Rs. 7,54,144-8-4 confirmed as correct, excluding inter-State oil sales and corresponding copra deduction entirely under s.26.

key_quotes.text: "I confess that I view with disfavour the doctrine that in taxation cases the subject is to be taxed if in accordance with a Courts view of what it considers the substance of the transaction..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms strict literal construction in fiscal statutes (from Duke of Westminster).

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act... a tax on the sale or purchase of goods shall not be imposed under this Act where such sale or purchase takes place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key non-obstante provision excluding inter-State sales from Act's purview.

key_quotes.text: s.26 "has the effect of setting at naught and of obliterating... the provisions contained in the Act relating to the imposition of tax... and in particular... r.20(2)".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on effect of s.26 on turnover calculations.
